results.title: They found a cave; Waxworks (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Andrew Steane, Charles E. Wolnizer and Australian Council for Children's Film and Television
results.brief_description: They found a cave: Four English orphans migrate to Tasmania under the care of their Aunt. Their Aunt becomes sick and is hospitalised, leaving the children to seek refuge in a secret cave. Excitement follows the children as they face danger and adventure in the rugged terrain before they are finally reunited with their Aunt. Based on the novel by Nan Chauncy. “Waxworks”: A short tale about children lost in a waxworks museum “House of Horrors”.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Andrew Steane, Charles E. Wolnizer and Australian Council for Children’s Film and Television

results.title: Sex: the Annabel Chong story (E)
results.creator_credit: Gough Lewis, David Whitten, Hugh F. Curry, Coffee House Films, Greycat Releasing and Omni International
results.brief_description: Annabel Chong was a university student in Los Angeles when she decided to enter the porn industry to finance her studies. This video commences soon after Annabel Chong has become famous for creating a world record in having sex with 251 men in one day. Resisting both a conservative and feminist anti-pornographic morality, Chong asserts her right as a woman and a feminist to both engage in the porn industry and to be unapologetic for her sexual desires and experience. But this ethically ambivalent documentary, filmed in a cinema-verite style in Chong’s home, on set of porn production houses in Los Angeles, and most disturbingly, in Chong’s parent’s home in Singapore, shows that for all the passion and sincerity of her passion, the pornographers creating, shaping and exploiting Chong’s sexual persona are all men. The filmmakers play on our voyeurism, beginning by titillating us and end up asking for our compassion: which makes for an uneasy but rivetting viewing experience. Annabel Chong, it needs to be said, is determined to refuse being portrayed as a victim. But ultimately sadness is the dominant emotion the viewer is left with by the end of this documentary. For all the apparent conviction of her beliefs, Annabel Chong seems immersed in a world in which she is used and exploited by men.

results.title: Meditation
results.creator_credit: Celia Tait, Brian Beaton, SBS-TV and Reel Images
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “The Nature of healing”.
Meditation is an ancient practice used to enhance enlightenment by altering metabolic processes to induce restfulness. Business people, patients and school students, in fact, everyone can benefit from the various therapies shwon if meditation is part of a daily routine.

results.title: They do come back
results.brief_description: Roy and Julie, two young working people, plan to marry, but TB interrupts their plans. Roy has advanced tuberculosis, and Julie is an early case. The film shows their town’s health facilities going into action to help these two young people; case-finding, diagnosis, and hospitalisation are demonstrated. Both Roy and Julie are admitted to a sanatorium, and after treatment, both are able to return to work, and to complete their plans for a home of their own.

results.title: Wolfe and Montcalm
results.creator_credit: Allan Wargon, Julian Biggs and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The film recreates the tense hours before the Battle of the Plains of Abraham (1759, Quebec), and then the battle itself in which both Generals Wolfe and Montcalm were fatally wounded.

results.title: What is the big complaint?
results.creator_credit: Salvatore Greco and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The difficulty in dialogue when a traveller from Ontario knowing very little French, must ask directions, becomes the core of a pleasant little episode in Quebec. Included are several men on the street’s views about the situation in Quebec.

results.title: The Nature of healing
results.creator_credit: Celia Tait, Brian Beaton, SBS-TV and Reel Images
results.brief_description: This 6 part series draws upon the combined knowledge of Eastern and Western medicine, and reveals techniques and therapies to achieve true health and harmony. It will change the way life and health is perceived.

results.title: Biomagnetism
results.creator_credit: Celia Tait, Brian Beaton, SBS-TV and Reel Images
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “The Nature of healing”.
This program looks at magnetic field therapy, an approach much researched, particularly in Japan. Biomagnetic therapy combined with drug therapy has been used to successfully treat depression, dementia, non-healing fractures and spinal injuries.

results.title: Brownie Movie Camera model 2
results.brief_description:
Kodak Brownie f/1.9 Improved Model II 8mm Movie Camera with case

STANDARD LENSES: Cine-Kodak Ektanon 13mm f/1.9
SPEED: 16 frames / second
VIEWFINDER:folding Sports Viewfinder
FILM: 8 mm

Kodak Dealer Catalogue 1960 Kodak (Australasia) PTY.Ltd:
A new and improved model of the popular 8mm. Brownie Movie Camera. This inexpensive movie camera provides all the fun of making sparkling 8mm. full-colour home movies with the simplicity of taking black- and white snapshots. All the user has to do is load, set the lens aperture pointer (according to the lighting conditions bright, dull, etc.), and press the button. A fast Lumenized 13mm. Cine Ektanon f/1.9 lens ensures bright sharp pictures. Sprocketless loading makes film threading easy and straightforward film is simply slipped into the gate and onto the take-up reel. Other features are: Long-running spring-driven motor; two-position exposure release; collapsible plastic viewfinder with parallax correction; easily read footage indicator; fingertip click stop aperture control; and handy tripod thread. Of aluminium con­struction, it is complete with a solid hide, velvet lined compartment case. Loads with doublerun Kodachrome Movie Film.

results.title: Homeopathy
results.creator_credit: Celia Tait, Brian Beaton, SBS-TV and Reel Images
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “The Nature of healing”.
Homoeopathy is a complementary medicine which is gradually gaining acceptance within traditional medicine. It is a therapy with a holistic approach, treating the causes rather than the symptoms of illness.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Celia Tait, Brian Beaton, SBS-TV and Reel Images
